posts.name: Ana Luiza Almeida
posts.cooked: how do you attach your bumper to the chassis of the robot? if you use angle brackets, how do you drill them correctly?

We use locking pins, and then CNC our angle brackets to percisely line up and drill the holes.

If we don’t use the CNC, we often use a punch on the metal, then just use a drill. If we need to line up holes with those on the robot, the bumpers are put on and then just drilled through.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We mount 10-32 screws (with the threads up) permanently in our robot perimeter, then place the bumpers on with angle aluminum mounted to the bumper and facing inward over that metal.

It is supported vertically on the metal, horizontally by being butted against the robot perimeter, and is fastened down with wing nuts (2 on each side) just to secure it from lifting off.

The angle has holes drilled (on our mill, but this is not a precision operation and could easily be done by hand and oversized holes are a help here as the robot takes damage or shifts around slightly over the season). We drill these holes on a 0.5” spacing (same as our perimeter) so that in the event some area becomes damaged or we need to mount a bracket on the outer rail for something that we can easily move to another spot. If you are drilling by hand, don’t do a full 0.5” spacing but give yourself a few extras.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
We have used the following rivet nuts for the last two seasons. Once installed, we have not had any come loose. They act like the plastic drywall anchors that expand behind the panel but are much stronger. We use a 1/4-20 hex head Grade 8 bolt to pull the lower threaded section up and cause the 4 “wings” to expand. A lower grade bolt will wear out after installing some number of these rivet nuts. A long wrench is necessary to get sufficient torque.

On the bumper side, we use a simple 90 degree bracket attached with four 1 inch long #10 sheet metal screws. We used four such brackets with full-wraparound bumpers and three on each section of the C-shaped bumpers. We purposely make the hole for the 1/4-20 bolt a loose fit to make installing the bumpers easy. We have found no advantage to making the hole a tight fit on the bolt. In fact, we feel it is better for the hole to be large enough to allow the bumper section to shift so that it’s full length comes into contact with the robot frame when it is hit. This spreads the forces over much of length of the side of the chassis instead of concentrating the forces at the bracket. Concentrating the forces can lead to breaking the bumper wood and/or the frame tube.

https://www.amazon.com/Moicstiy-Zinc-Plated-Construction-Fasteners-Industrial/dp/B0B7JG1RF7

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
theworkshope:

When we’ve used right angle brackets, we cut them to length, use a 3D printed template to accurately place the holes that go into the chassis, drill press using the template, and roughly drill the holes that will go into the wood bumpers.

We typically have a metal top plate that is CNC laser cut, so the holes there are accurately placed. The brackets would get bolted onto the robot frame, then the bumpers placed on blocks to get to the correct height before screwing in.

That process has worked pretty well. The 3d printed template was key.

That process has worked pretty well. The 3d printed template was key.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
In the past, we used angle brackets to attach bumpers. Pre-drilled angle is your friend ; if you make your own, treat it like any other precision part, complete with tolerances.  Bumper backing also needs to be cut precisely to fit, or at least matched to the robot.

Last off-season, we adopted these mounts from Citrus Circuits .

link_counts.title: 1678 Citrus Circuits 2023 CAD and Code Release

posts.cooked: We switched to the Citrus bumper mounts this season and they have been amazing. The bumpers are very securely mounted and with a Milwaukee electric ratchet it can be removed or attached by one person in less than a minute.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
It was an idea somebody else posted here in a different thread.   Based on this latch: https://shop.southco.com/en_us/r4-05-21-405-10

We had brackets cut at Sendcutsend out of 1/8" aluminum (~$4 each in quantity) that attach to the latch and to the to the top of our 2x1 aluminum.   The screw is a #10-32 partially-threaded alloy-steel socket-head that (IIRC) is 2 1/2 inches long.   On the foam-cushion side of the bumper, there’s a nylock nut and a washer, and on the inside there’s a washer and an “ordinary” nut that presses against the washer.  We used a forstner bit on the wood to recess a bit for the washer.

The one thing that I think we’ll do differently next year is to have the latch sit slightly above the side rail.  It sometimes jams because it needs a tiny bit of clearance.

One other thing that we’ve learned:  Once you have your bumper frames and latches put together, you want to make sure not to add tape or bumper fabric between the bumper frame and the robot frame.

Attached is a document we made that describes how we have mounted bumpers for years.  It only has simple to manufacture parts and items you can buy at your local hardware store.

It also describes how we align our holes in the angle mounted to the bumper with the hardware on our robot.

PantherBots Bumper R1.pdf (735.0 KB)

posts.name: 71ct74rtav
posts.cooked: @Suppdog222 We use metal to wood screws but we put wood glue on the ends of them before we screw them into the wood, The length we use is also around 5/8 inch so they dont penetrate out the back.
